sub.page.title: Explanation: Algebraic Properties of the Cross Product

block.para: Let us analyze a bit what the equations describing the algebraic properties of the cross product actually say.

li.para: The three equations in i. together say that the cross product operation is bilinear.
The equation in ii. says that the cross product is alternating.
The equation \CrssPr{(\Vect{u}+\Vect{v})}{\Vect{y}} = (\CrssPr{ \Vect{u} }{ \Vect{y} }) + (\CrssPr{ \Vect{v} }{\Vect{y}}) says that the cross product is additive in the first variable.
The equation \CrssPr{\Vect{u}}{(\Vect{x} + \Vect{y})} = (\CrssPr{ \Vect{u} }{ \Vect{x} }) + (\CrssPr{ \Vect{u} }{\Vect{y}}) says that the cross product is additive in the second variable.

The equations \CrssPr{ (t\cdot \Vect{x}) }{ \Vect{y} } = t\cdot (\CrssPr{ \Vect{x} }{ \Vect{y} }) = \CrssPr{ \Vect{x} }{ (t\cdot \Vect{y}) } say that the cross product commutes with scalar multiplication in each variable.

block.para: Combined these equations say that the cross product is a linear function \RNr[3]\to \RNr[3] in each of its two variables.

The equation \CrssPr{ \Vect{x} }{ \Vect{y} } = -(\CrssPr{ \Vect{y} }{ \Vect{x} }) says that the cross product switches its sign if we interchange the two vectors. So the cross product is an alternating function.
